Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Self-Aggregation of Moist Convection, Radiative-Convective Instability, and the Regulation of Tropical Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical showers and thunderstorms play an important role in the regulation of Earth's climate. One theory regarding tropical convection is that as sea surface temperatures warm, more clouds form and the atmosphere becomes drier. While the clouds reduce solar radiation from warming the surface, that effect is more than counteracted by a drier atmosphere allowing more outgoing radiation to pass. This could suggest that the tropical climate has a level of self-regulation. To study this idea, the researchers involved in this project have created an idealized computer model to address what they call the "self-aggregation" of convection. This is the tendency for clouds and thunderstorms to move together into clusters. This award will provide funding to enhance the model with more realistic wind and sea surface temperatures. The impact of this research would be through improvements in the representation of tropical convection in weather and climate models. The project would also help to train the next generation of scientists by involving multiple graduate students in the research.

The overarching goal of the project is to understand how aggregation of convection in an environment more realistically representative of the tropics may help regulate tropical climate. The related hypothesis is that aggregation reduces tropical climate sensitivity by providing a powerful negative water vapor feedback that is highly temperature dependent. The researchers will introduce a diurnal cycle and wind shear to their simulations in order to decrease or eliminate the strong aggregation state lock that they found in their prior work. Sea surface temperatures would also be allowed to vary, which will let the researchers test the hypothesis that the existence of aggregation may drive the system's climate toward the critical sea surface temperature for aggregation. The next step will be to use the theoretical model to explore the climate sensitivity of the system by varying the solar constant and CO2. Finally, the researchers will test the hypothesis that the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) results from self-aggregation of convection independent of larger atmospheric waves.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the project was to better understand the physical mechanisms that control and regulate the tropical weather and climate. It is observed that the cloud systems in the tropical atmosphere tend to organize into large clusters. Among them are hurricanes. However, the biggest clusters of convection in tropics are not hurricanes, but the wave-like disturbances, which travel eastward over the warmest parts of the Indian and Pacific Ocean producing anomalous precipitation that affects millions of people who live in tropical regions.These regularly occurring clusters of convection are called the Madden-Julian Oscillation ("MJO"). The MJO also may create favorable conditions for development of hurricanes. Many theories of MJO have been proposed since its discovery in 1970s, but the complete understanding remains elusive. In this research, we have proposed that it is the cooling by the infrared radiation interacting with clouds and water vapor that helps to organize the tropical convection into super-large clusters like the MJO. In a nutshell, in our theory, the MJO is the result of a powerful positive feedback loop when clouds block the infrared radiation escaping to space, thus effectively warming the atmosphere and creating rising motion, which helps to form more clouds yet. We used a state-of-the-art computer model of clouds, run on one of the most powerful supercomputers, to simulate the development and propagation of the MJO. The computer model has allowed us to modify various physical processes to see which of them may be most responsible for MJO development and propagation. For example, we found that the eastward propagation of MJO is because winds to the east of the MJO are stronger and produce more evaporation. We also found that artificially cutting the proposed radiation-cloud feedback loop prevents the development of simulated MJO. The model has also been able to simulate other common tropical disturbances that are observed in the tropical atmosphere. For example, we found how dependence of the evaporation on wind speed can affect their excitation.

The success in simulating the MJO and curiosity on how the tropical weather phenomena may affect the weather outside the tropics motivated us to expand the model domain from tropics to the whole planet and, with support from this grant, develop one of the most comprehensive global computer models that resolve clouds. The new global cloud resolving model has successfully debuted in a very first international model inter-comparison project, where it was favorably compared to the results from other such models. The model will be used to better understand the self-organization of clouds on our planet and how clouds affect the present and future climate.
